Unlicensed driving is not only an illegal practice but also calls for broader policies that address lifestyle and mobility options for young people.  Policies that are credible and relevant should encourage compliance with existing licensing practices to deter young people from driving unlicensed.  Develop and promote transportation options in areas where the availability of opportunities are limited.  Promote policies inclusive of multiple funding streams that involve traffic safety and other youth health and safety efforts addressing fundamental developmental and mobility issues.  Encourage car owners not to give permission to drive unlicensed and monitor the unauthorized use of their vehicles.

During the transition to driving support needs to be provided where risk for unlicensed driving is highest not only to eliminate unlicensed driving, but to bolster opportunities for independence by addressing the fundamental mobility issues.  Social marketing campaigns and influential adults in schools, athletics, government, and health care should provide pre-driving anticipatory guidance for safe and responsible attitudes and behaviors. Guidance should include both driving and riding unlicensed.  Broaden the availability of driver training to public venues such as schools that provide equal access to all youth.  Encourage data gathering practices in the US for a national registry for nonfatal crashes (similar to FARS) and reliable state licensing data to assess scope and risk of unlicensed driving.  Work to implement overall road safety improvements that address young driver risk including rigorous enforcement of existing licensing and driving practices, focusing on areas where unlicensed driving risk is high.

In both countries, crashes involving a YUD are an objective measure of unlicensed driver characteristics and circumstances demonstrating conclusively a measurable proportion of crash involvement. Studies on RTC and self-reported health risk behaviors suggest that driving unlicensed among the young is a common health risk behavior, even past the age of eligibility of licensing. It is more frequent among males and some socio-demographic groups of young people. It is accompanied with other health risk behaviors and can be more prevalent is some area types. To address the issue will require multi-disciplinary targeted efforts to both discourage unlicensed driving and promote developmental opportunities with safe youth mobility options.

First, to my fellow PhD students who turn first to the acknowledgements to see their name, I salute you all. Those that impacted my "going" experience at KI are too numerous to mention from recall. You know who you are, and I acknowledge you foremost. Thank you for welcoming a road traffic thesis to your global health agenda. Long distance education has not been easy, but the support from KI and IHCAR faculty and administrative staff made the process seamless. On the journey, I appreciated my halftime committee and the pre-defense seminar. I owe special appreciation to Klara Johannson, Lisa Blom, Netta Beer, and Berty Elling who were my eyes, ears, arms, and legs at KI in my absence. The members of the ISAC group are my heroes and source of encouragement. When I struggled, I was encouraged by an expression that was shared with me: "if research were easy, everyone would be doing it." My family and children, Christina, Grace, and Häkkon (Hawk) who I am so proud of and inspire me; my Mom (M) and Dad (H) and in-laws Rosemary and Tom (RIP) whose support was appreciated; continuing gratitude to my brothers Mark and Matthew and their families; and the dance partner for the rest of my life---my dear wife Loretta who without question made the biggest sacrifices. This could not have been possible without my co-authors Dexter Taylor, Monique Sheppard, Marie Hasselberg, Jette Möller, C. Raymond Bingham, Berty Elling, and Lucie Laflamme whose support and guidance through the publication process was priceless. Visiting Sweden and Stockholm has been a pleasure and a chance to get in touch with my Nordic roots. I enjoyed the sights, sounds, tastes, and smells, and the weather on occasion. My visits have been boosted by staying with Christina & Sten Noren as a home away from home and a great service to international students. Along the way, folks that include the EloQuents Toastmasters Club in Okemos; Michigan State University graduate writing group; friends and colleagues that include Barbara Marlenga, Takashi Nagata, Patrick Tobin, Alda Pires, and Peter Lindqvist have taken an interest. Finally, a special dedication to a fellow Toastmaster and bicyclist, Sue Maus, who was hit by a young driver while bike riding on September 9 of this year. Sue lost her leg---but not her spirit. Last, but not least Professor Lucie Laflamme, a supervisor with patience and persistence, who ALWAYS made the time and energy to guide me gracefully toward being an independent researcher/scientist. I hope my future contributions can equal the opportunity given to me. Your commitment to the KI, Department of Public Health Sciences, IHCAR, ISAC, students, travels, and global obligations speaks of your commitment to public health. Fellow students were envious of my supervision for which I always felt privileged. I wish you, Lars, and Catherine all the best from my family to yours. Peace.
